bioghist.p: Villanova University traces its origins to old Saint Augustine's Church in Philadelphia, which the Augustinians founded in 1796, and to its parish school, Saint Augustine's Academy, established in 1811. Villanova University has been sponsored by the Augustinian Order since its founding in 1842. Today, the University is comprised of five colleges: Liberal Arts and Sciences (Villanova College), Engineering, School of Business (formerly known as the College of Commerce and Finance), Nursing and the School of Law. Institutional Advancement at Villanova is responsible for a range of activities which provide the framework for building strong support and lasting relationships with a variety of University constituencies, including alumni, parents, friends, and members of the community.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers related to University advancement and includes records from several departments. Records for the Vice President for Institutional Advancement consist of three series: Correspondence, News Media, and Reports. Correspondence makes up the bulk of the materials. This series includes general correspondence (1968-1985) and materials related to the Higher Education Facilities Authority Act (1968-1969); the Master Plan for Higher Education (1966-1969); the Pennsylvania Association of Colleges and Universities (1966-1971); and Citizens for Educational Freedom-Pennsylvania Federation (1969-1970). Other correspondence relates to public relations and public hearings on tax reforms. News Media consists of clippings about the Master Plan for Higher Education (1963-1967). The collection also includes a printed proposal by the Pennsylvania Association of Colleges and Universities (1971). Records related to communications and public affairs include press releases, calendars, fact sheets, visitorâ€™s guides, and campus maps. The series also includes 30 scrapbooks of newspaper clippings on Villanova students, faculty, campus, events, and athletics, 1930-1955 and 1954-1993. Development records include: correspondence, minutes, and reports of the Development Council; correspondence, minutes, charter and by-laws, and brochures of the Development Foundation; Handbook for Faculty and Staff on Foundations, 1968; newspaper clippings; printed brochures, and reports. Materials related to the Alumni Association include: minutes of the Alumni Association Board of Governors; minutes of the Alumni Association Long-Range Planning Committee; annual reports; resource guide; correspondence; and papers related to the Alumni Association Constitution. The collection also includes programs for inaugurations of endowed chairs, 1992-2006.
